Summing geometric progressions

We will use the alternative name geometric progression to refer to a finite number of terms from a geometric sequence.

Adding up the first \(n\) terms of the geometric sequence given by \(u_n=ar^{n-1}\), we have \[ \begin{align*} S_n &= u_1+u_2+\cdots+u_n \\ &= a + ar + ar^2 + \cdots + ar^{n-1}. \end{align*} \] Writing out \(S_n\) and \(r\times S_n\) in full, \[ \begin{align*} S_n &= a + ar + ar^2 + \cdots + ar^{n-1} \\ r\times S_n &= \phantom{a +{}} ar + ar^2 + \cdots + ar^{n-1} + ar^n, \end{align*} \] so we see that \[ \begin{align*} S_n - r S_n &= a - ar^n \\ (1-r)S_n &= a(1-r^n). \end{align*} \] This can be rearranged to get the formula for the sum of the first \(n\) terms:


The sum of the first \(n\) terms of the geometric sequence given by \(u_n=ar^{n-1}\) is \[ S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r}. \]


Note that the formula does not work if \(r=1\) since that would result in dividing by \(0\). But when \(r=1\) we just have \(S_n = a+a+a+\cdots+a=na\).


Example

What is the sum of the geometric progression \(81+27+9+\cdots+\frac{1}{81}\)?

Solution

In case case, we see that the first term of the progression is \(a = 81\) and common ratio is \(r = \frac{27}{81} = \frac{1}{3}\). The final term is \[ \frac{1}{81} = ar^{n-1} = 81(\frac{1}{3})= 81(\frac{1}{3})^{n-1}. \] Therefore, \[ (\frac{1}{3})^{n-1} = \frac{1}{81^2}=\frac{1}{3^8}. \] Hence, \(n-1 = 8\) and so \(n=9\). We are now in a position to use the formula above as follows \[ S_9 = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} = \frac{81(1-\frac{1}{3^9})}{1-\frac{1}{3}} = \frac{9841}{81} \]
